doom.driver: British military base in Cyprus targeted in suspected drone attack. The attack marks the first strike on a British military base in Cyprus since 1986, escalating regional tensions.
doom.blurb: THE WAR JUST HIT A NATO ALLY'S DOORSTEP
doom.summary: Iran's retaliatory strikes have now reached a British military installation in Cyprus — the first such attack since 1986 — while explosions light up Qatar, UAE, and Kuwait simultaneously. With three U.S. F-15s down to friendly fire, oil approaching $80 a barrel, and the Strait of Hormuz looking increasingly theoretical as a shipping lane, this conflict has graduated from 'Middle East crisis' to 'everyone's problem.' The DHS is now warning of lone-wolf attacks on U.S. soil, which is a sentence no one wanted to read on a Monday.

factors.name: Geopolitics
factors.detail: Iran's retaliatory strikes now span Cyprus, Kuwait, Qatar, UAE, and Israel simultaneously — the conflict is actively regionalizing into a multi-front war.

factors.name: Governance
factors.detail: Congress is moving to challenge Trump's war powers, the UK has authorized U.S. use of British bases, and Iran's leadership succession remains dangerously unclear.

factors.name: AI Capability
factors.detail: Claude hit #1 on the U.S. App Store — notable growth, but firmly background noise against an active shooting war.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: An Austin shooter was found with Iranian flag imagery, a prediction market trader made $553K on Khamenei's death, and the Strait of Hormuz closure could crater the global economy within days.

factors.name: Alignment
factors.detail: No major AI alignment developments today — the humans are generating enough existential risk on their own.

dawn.driver: New iron nanomaterial wipes out cancer cells without harming healthy tissue. Scientists at Oregon State University have engineered a powerful new nanomaterial that zeroes in on cancer cells and destroys them from the inside out. Designed to exploit cancer's unique chemistry—it
dawn.summary: Even as the world burns with war headlines, Oregon State scientists have achieved something quietly extraordinary: a nanomaterial that hunts cancer cells by exploiting their own chemistry, destroying them from within while leaving healthy tissue untouched. This is the kind of precision medicine breakthrough that decades of research has been building toward — targeted, elegant, humane. On a day when so much destruction feels indiscriminate, science offers the opposite: a weapon that knows exactly what it's fighting.

factors.name: Science
factors.detail: Oregon State's iron nanomaterial exploits cancer's unique biochemistry to selectively destroy malignant cells, a significant leap toward treatments with far fewer devastating side effects.

factors.name: Cooperation
factors.detail: India and Canada struck a uranium deal and set a $50bn bilateral trade target, showing two democracies deepening economic ties despite a turbulent geopolitical backdrop.

factors.name: Human Spirit
factors.detail: A 6-year-old boy coaching alongside his father on a high school basketball team became a viral moment of pure, uncomplicated joy amid a relentlessly grim news cycle.

factors.name: Environment
factors.detail: New crystal seeding methods have pushed perovskite solar cell efficiency to 23%, nudging low-cost solar power closer to mainstream grid viability.

factors.name: Wild Card
factors.detail: EV battery lifespans are significantly exceeding early expectations, quietly undermining one of the last major consumer anxieties holding back the electric vehicle transition.

dawn.dalle_prompt: Pixel art, 16-bit SNES style, no text, no antialiasing. Night scene inside a darkened university research laboratory, deep shadows consuming the edges of the room, every light source artificial and deliberate — cool blue-white fluorescent strips overhead casting long clinical shadows across black benchtops, but the dominant glow is warm amber and rust-orange radiating from a central glass vial held aloft by a woman in a white lab coat, her face illuminated from below by the nanoagent's ember-like light, expression calm and certain. The vial glows like a lantern in the dark room, its amber light spilling across nearby centrifuge machines and microscopy equipment. On a large monitor screen behind her, false-color cellular imagery pulses in deep purple-black — tumor cells visibly collapsing inward, losing their borders, dissolving — while clusters of healthy cells nearby glow soft peach-rose, untouched and luminous. Floating in the microscopic visualization on screen, tiny geometric crystalline lattice structures in rust-orange and amber — iron nanoparticles shaped like glowing geodesic cages — crackle with electric-blue sparks and soft gold-green orbs erupting inside dark tumor mass. Two colleagues lean toward a second glowing screen at the far bench, their silhouettes backlit, pointing at regression data. The outside window behind them is pure night black. Warm amber and soft green dominate, shadows lifting only where the glowing science burns through the dark.
